user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_bd_prog:
```c
static int lfs_bd_prog(lfs_t *lfs,
        lfs_cache_t *pcache, lfs_cache_t *rcache, bool validate,
        lfs_block_t block, lfs_off_t off,
        const void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    const uint8_t *data = buffer;
    LFS_ASSERT(block == LFS_BLOCK_INLINE || block < lfs->block_count);
    LFS_ASSERT(off + size <= lfs->cfg->block_size);

    while (size > 0) {
        if (block == pcache->block &&
                off >= pcache->off &&
                off < pcache->off + lfs->cfg->cache_size) {
            // already fits in pcache?
            lfs_size_t diff = lfs_min(size,
                    lfs->cfg->cache_size - (off-pcache->off));
            memcpy(&pcache->buffer[off-pcache->off], data, diff);

            data += diff;
            off += diff;
            size -= diff;

            pcache->size = lfs_max(pcache->size, off - pcache->off);
            if (pcache->size == lfs->cfg->cache_size) {
                // eagerly flush out pcache if we fill up
                int err = lfs_bd_flush(lfs, pcache, rcache, validate);
                if (err) {
                    return err;
                }
            }

            continue;
        }

        // pcache must have been flushed, either by programming and
        // entire block or manually flushing the pcache
        LFS_ASSERT(pcache->block == LFS_BLOCK_NULL);

        // prepare pcache, first condition can no longer fail
        pcache->block = block;
        pcache->off = lfs_aligndown(off, lfs->cfg->prog_size);
        pcache->size = 0;
    }

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_bd_prog:
typedef struct lfs_cache {
    lfs_block_t block;
    lfs_off_t off;
    lfs_size_t size;
    uint8_t *buffer;
} lfs_cache_t
...
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
...
typedef uint32_t lfs_off_t
...
typedef uint32_t lfs_size_t
...
typedef uint32_t lfs_block_t
...
#define LFS_BLOCK_INLINE ((lfs_block_t)-2)
...
#define LFS_BLOCK_NULL ((lfs_block_t)-1)
...
#define LFS_ASSERT(test) assert(test)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only use of a string.h function in this function is memcpy, therefore only the if-block containing the memcpy call needs investigation for potential out-of-bounds accesses. Other parts of the function do not invoke any string.h functions and thus are not relevant to MISRA C Rule 21.17. The initial assertion LFS_ASSERT(off + size <= lfs->cfg->block_size) constrains the overall requested write range within a block. The if-condition (off >= pcache->off && off < pcache->off + lfs->cfg->cache_size) together with diff = lfs_min(size, lfs->cfg->cache_size - (off-pcache->off)) bounds the destination range passed to memcpy to within the cache window. The subsequent updates (data += diff; off += diff; size -= diff) maintain the remaining source/data length tracked by size; there are no other memcpy/memmove/strcpy/strncpy/strcat/strncat/memset/memcmp/strlen/strspn calls in this function. Therefore other code fragments in this function do not need to be investigated under Rule 21.17.
